metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: SVG Stroke Attributes
SVG Stroke Attributes
The stroke attribute sets the color of the line drawn around an element.
content.html: The stroke attribute sets the color of the line drawn around an element.

content.text: Here we will look at the six stroke attributes:
content.html: Here we will look at the six stroke attributes:

content.text: SVG stroke Attribute
The stroke attribute defines the color of the outline of an element.
content.html: The stroke attribute defines the color of the outline of an element.

content.text: The stroke attribute can be used with the following SVG elements: <circle> , <ellipse> , <line> , <path> , <polygon> , <polyline> , <rect> , <text> , <textPath> , <tref> and <tspan> .
content.html: The stroke attribute can be used with the following SVG elements: <circle>, <ellipse>, <line>, <path>, <polygon>, <polyline>, <rect>, <text>, <textPath>, <tref> and <tspan>.

content.text: The value of the stroke attribute can be a color name, rgb value or a hex value.
content.html: The value of the stroke attribute can be a color name, rgb value or a hex value.

content.text: Here we use the stroke attribute to set the outline color for a polygon, rectangle, circle and a text:
content.html: Here we use the stroke attribute to set the outline color for a polygon, rectangle, circle and a text:

content.text: Here is the SVG code:
content.html: Here is the SVG code:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<rect 
  width="150" height="100" x="120" y="50" fill="yellow" stroke="red" />
width="150" height="100" x="120" y="50" fill="yellow" stroke="red" /

content.code:
<svg width="600" height="220" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  
<polygon points="50,10 0,190 100,190" fill="lime" stroke="red" />
  <rect 
width="150" height="100" x="120" y="50" fill="yellow" stroke="red" />
  
<circle r="45" cx="350" cy="100" fill="pink" stroke="blue" />
  <text 
x="420" y="100" fill="red" stroke="blue">I love SVG!</text>
</svg>

width="150" height="100" x="120" y="50" fill="yellow" stroke="red" /

  <rect width="150" height="100" x="120" y="50" fill="yellow" stroke="red" />
  <circle r="45" cx="350" cy="100" fill="pink" stroke="blue" />
  <text x="420" y="100" fill="red" stroke="blue">I love SVG!</text>
</svg>

content.text: Here we use the stroke attribute to define the color of three lines:
content.html: Here we use the stroke attribute to define the color of three lines:

content.text: Here is the SVG code:
content.html: Here is the SVG code:

content.code:
<svg height="80" width="300" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">

<g fill="none">

<path stroke="red" d="M5 20 l215 0" />

<path stroke="green" d="M5 40 l215 0" />

<path stroke="blue" d="M5 60 l215 0" />

</g>

</svg>
content.code_html:
<svg height="80" width="300" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <g fill="none">
    <path stroke="red" d="M5 20 l215 0" />
    <path stroke="green" d="M5 40 l215 0" />
    <path stroke="blue" d="M5 60 l215 0" />
  </g>
</svg>

content.text: SVG stroke-width Attribute
The stroke-width attribute defines the width of the stroke.
content.html: The stroke-width attribute defines the width of the stroke.

content.text: The stroke-width attribute can be used with the following SVG elements: <circle> , <ellipse> , <line> , <path> , <polygon> , <polyline> , <rect> , <text> , <textPath> , <tref> and <tspan> .
content.html: The stroke-width attribute can be used with the following SVG elements: <circle>, <ellipse>, <line>, <path>, <polygon>, <polyline>, <rect>, <text>, <textPath>, <tref> and <tspan>.

content.text: Here we use the stroke-width attribute to set the width of the outline for a polygon, rectangle, circle and a text:
content.html: Here we use the stroke-width attribute to set the width of the outline for a polygon, rectangle, circle and a text:

content.text: Here is the SVG code:
content.html: Here is the SVG code:

content.html: Here we use the stroke-width attribute to set the width of three lines:

content.html: Here is the SVG code:

<g fill="none" stroke="red">

<path stroke-width="2" d="M5 20 l215 0" />

<path stroke-width="4" d="M5 40 l215 0" />

<path stroke-width="6" d="M5 60 l215 0" />

</g>

</svg>

content.text: SVG stroke-opacity Attribute
The stroke-opacity attribute defines the opacity of the stroke.
content.html: The stroke-opacity attribute defines the opacity of the stroke.

content.text: The stroke-opacity attribute can be used with the following SVG elements: <circle> , <ellipse> , <line> , <path> , <polygon> , <polyline> , <rect> , <text> , <textPath> , <tref> and <tspan> .
content.html: The stroke-opacity attribute can be used with the following SVG elements: <circle>, <ellipse>, <line>, <path>, <polygon>, <polyline>, <rect>, <text>, <textPath>, <tref> and <tspan>.

content.text: The value of the stroke-opacity attribute goes from 0 to 1 (or 0% to 100%).
content.html: The value of the stroke-opacity attribute goes from 0 to 1 (or 0% to 100%).

content.text: Here we use the stroke-opacity attribute to set the opacity of the outline for a polygon, rectangle, circle and a text:
content.html: Here we use the stroke-opacity attribute to set the opacity of the outline for a polygon, rectangle, circle and a text:

content.text: Here is the SVG code:
content.html: Here is the SVG code:

content.text: Here we use the stroke-opacity attribute to set the opacity of three lines:
content.html: Here we use the stroke-opacity attribute to set the opacity of three lines:

content.text: Here is the SVG code:
content.html: Here is the SVG code:

content.code:
<svg height="80" width="300" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">

<g fill="none" stroke="red">

<path stroke-width="2" stroke-opacity="0.4" d="M5 20 l215 0" />

<path stroke-width="4" stroke-opacity="0.4" d="M5 40 l215 0" />

<path stroke-width="6" stroke-opacity="0.4" d="M5 60 l215 0" />

</g>

</svg>
content.code_html:
<svg height="80" width="300" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <g fill="none" stroke="red">
    <path stroke-width="2" stroke-opacity="0.4" d="M5 20 l215 0" />
    <path stroke-width="4" stroke-opacity="0.4" d="M5 40 l215 0" />
    <path stroke-width="6" stroke-opacity="0.4" d="M5 60 l215 0" />
  </g>
</svg>

content.text: SVG stroke-linecap Attribute
The stroke-linecap attribute defines different types of endings for a line or an open path.
content.html: The stroke-linecap attribute defines different types of endings for a line or an open path.

content.text: The stroke-linecap attribute can be used with the following SVG elements: <path> , <polyline> , <line> , <text> , <textPath> , <tref> and <tspan> .
content.html: The stroke-linecap attribute can be used with the following SVG elements: <path>, <polyline>, <line>, <text>, <textPath>, <tref> and <tspan>.

content.text: The value of the stroke-linecap attribute can be "butt", "round" or "square".
content.html: The value of the stroke-linecap attribute can be "butt", "round" or "square".

content.text: Here we use the stroke-linecap attribute to set different endings for three lines:
content.html: Here we use the stroke-linecap attribute to set different endings for three lines:

content.text: Here is the SVG code:
content.html: Here is the SVG code:

content.code:
<svg height="120" width="300" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <g fill="none" stroke="red" 
stroke-width="16">
    <path stroke-linecap="butt" d="M10 20 
l215 0" />
    <path stroke-linecap="round" d="M10 50 l215 
0" />
    <path stroke-linecap="square" d="M10 80 l215 0" />
  
</g>
</svg>
content.code_html:
<svg height="120" width="300" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <g fill="none" stroke="red" stroke-width="16">
    <path stroke-linecap="butt" d="M10 20 l215 0" />
    <path stroke-linecap="round" d="M10 50 l215 0" />
    <path stroke-linecap="square" d="M10 80 l215 0" />
  </g>
</svg>

content.text: SVG stroke-dasharray Attribute
The stroke-dasharray attribute is used to create dashed lines.
content.html: The stroke-dasharray attribute is used to create dashed lines.

content.text: The stroke-dasharray attribute can be used with the following SVG elements: <circle> , <ellipse> , <line> , <path> , <polygon> , <polyline> , <rect> , <text> , <textPath> , <tref> and <tspan> .
content.html: The stroke-dasharray attribute can be used with the following SVG elements: <circle>, <ellipse>, <line>, <path>, <polygon>, <polyline>, <rect>, <text>, <textPath>, <tref> and <tspan>.

content.text: The value of the stroke-dasharray attribute can be "none" or a comma or space separated list of lengths/percentages that define the lengths of dashes and gaps.
content.html: The value of the stroke-dasharray attribute can be "none" or a comma or space separated list of lengths/percentages that define the lengths of dashes and gaps.

content.text: Here we use the stroke-dasharray attribute to create different dashed lines:
content.html: Here we use the stroke-dasharray attribute to create different dashed lines:

content.text: Here is the SVG code:
content.html: Here is the SVG code:

content.code:
<svg height="100" width="400" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <g 
fill="none" stroke="red" stroke-width="6">
    <path stroke-dasharray="5,5" 
d="M5 20 l215 0" />
    <path stroke-dasharray="10,10" d="M5 
40 l215 0" />
    <path stroke-dasharray="35,10" d="M5 60 
l215 0" />
    <path stroke-dasharray="20,10,5,5,5,10" d="M5 
80 l215 0" />
  </g>
</svg>
content.code_html:
<svg height="100" width="400" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <g fill="none" stroke="red" stroke-width="6">
    <path stroke-dasharray="5,5" d="M5 20 l215 0" />
    <path stroke-dasharray="10,10" d="M5 40 l215 0" />
    <path stroke-dasharray="35,10" d="M5 60 l215 0" />
    <path stroke-dasharray="20,10,5,5,5,10" d="M5 80 l215 0" />
  </g>
</svg>

content.text: SVG stroke-linejoin Attribute
The stroke-linejoin attribute defines the shape of the corners where two lines meet.
content.html: The stroke-linejoin attribute defines the shape of the corners where two lines meet.

content.text: The stroke-linejoin attribute can be used with the following SVG elements: <path> , <polygon> , <polyline> , <rect> , <text> , <textPath> , <tref> and <tspan> .
content.html: The stroke-linejoin attribute can be used with the following SVG elements: <path>, <polygon>, <polyline>, <rect>, <text>, <textPath>, <tref> and <tspan>.

content.text: The value of the stroke-linejoin attribute can be "arcs", "bevel", "miter", miter-clip" or "round".
content.html: The value of the stroke-linejoin attribute can be "arcs", "bevel", "miter", miter-clip" or "round".

content.text: Here we use the stroke-linejoin attribute to create different corner shapes:
content.html: Here we use the stroke-linejoin attribute to create different corner shapes:

content.html: Here is the SVG code:
